newsitem.title: USA: GOLF-BOBBY WADKINS LEADS AFTER FIRST ROUND OF BUICK CHALLENGE.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-BOBBY WADKINS LEADS AFTER FIRST ROUND OF BUICK CHALLENGE.

text.p: Veteran Bobby Wadkins, a non-winner in 658 events on the PGA Tour, putted superbly to lead after the first round at the $1 million Buick Challenge on Thursday.
"I putted like Ben Crenshaw. I have his caddie this week. Maybe it's rubbing off on me," Wadkins said after a bogey-free eight-under-par 64 in a testing breeze at pretty Callaway Gardens.
He stood one stroke ahead of fellow American Jim McGovern, while Davis Love, Olin Browne, Michael Bradley, Stewart Cink and Len Mattiace were two shots behind.

Wadkins, 45, has the dubious record of earning more prize money than any other non-winner on tour. He has accumulated $2,551,570 since joining the tour in 1975, enough to live very comfortably, but not necessarily earn the ovewhelming respect of his fellow professionals, who judge their peers by victories.
"It makes you wonder if there's a reason why you put in all the hard work," he said. "Today's the reason why you keep coming to work every day. Nobody is more surprised than me.
"I've led a bunch of tournaments, but never at the very end. Hopefully this will be the week.
"I'm in no-man's zone. Being 45, I'm not old enough for the Senior Tour, and a little too old for the kids out here.
"The best part of my game is the driver, and if you drive the ball well here you have a chance to make some birdies. I like the course."
Wadkins made six birdies, plus an eagle at the par-five seventh where he sank a 35-footer.
Several well-known players were within striking distance, including Love, who helped the United States retain the Presidents Cup against the Internationals two weeks ago.
Love was not happy with his game early, despite an eagle at the second hole.
"My ball-striking was a little shaky at first," he said. "I started out missing fairways and a few greens but I was still scoring."
Despite a breeze and wiry rough, the field averaged a low 71.5 strokes, mainly because the four par-fives all played easily.
